comment._content: Well, as I recall, Walter Camp invented the "forward pass" in the early 1900s. They did throw the ball in the backfield, mostly laterals. The ball back then was a bit rounder and harder to pass compared to the modern day ball. Football was more a running game, more like rugby. I wish there were more old movies to watch of football. Most of the films I have seen are very brief and from a distance. They had some interesting film strips of Jim Thorpe playing around 1915 on a recent special about him. I can't recall if that was on PBS or on the History Channel. I think it is incredible that the Carlisle Indian School could beat powerful teams like Army. Carlisle Indian School was not even a college. There is no question in my mind that Jim Thorpe was the most talented athlete of all time. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlisle_Indian_Industrial_School Here is something I found on the forward pass. Claims it was invented at UNC. Hard to say. tarheelmania.wordpress.com/2007/09/13/unc-invented-the-fo...
